entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 1:16AM CST by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
At 116 AM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 14 miles east of The Intersection Of Us- 277 And Ranch Road 189, or 16 miles southeast of Sonora, moving east at 45 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Junction, South Llano River State Park, Roosevelt, Cleo, and I-10 Near The Sutton-kKmble County Line.
This includes Interstate 10 between Mile Markers 411 and 460.

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT NORTHWESTERN KIMBLE...SOUTH CENTRAL MENARD AND SOUTHEASTERN SUTTON COUNTIES THROUGH 200 AM CST

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 8 at 1:06AM CST until March 8 at 3:30AM CST by NWS Springfield MO
entry.summary:
At 106 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated that the heavy rainfall that occurred Thursday evening across the warned area had ended. Scattered light to moderate rainfall will continue to occur overnight. Between 1.5 and 3.5 inches of rain have fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Carthage, Greenfield, Lockwood, Jasper, Golden City, Carytown, South Greenfield, Dudenville, Meinert, Maple Grove, Red Oak, Kenoma, Boston, Pennsboro and Stockton Lake.
This includes the following low water crossings... Sinking Creek at County Road 181, Muddy Creek at Highway 126, Lousy Branch at County Road 85, Sons Creek at County Road 113 and Dry Fork at Pine Road.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Barton, MO; Dade, MO; Jasper, MO; Lawrence, MO

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 7 at 9:31PM AKST until March 9 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW FOR HAINES HIGHWAY AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS...
.Heavy snow beginning tonight will move into the Haines and Haines Highway area. Warm moisture will overrun cooler air at the surface, producing heavy snow and raising snow levels over time. As the warm air moves over Haines, snow will become increasingly wet and heavy, limiting snow totals. For areas 600 feet and above, such as Haines Customs, precipitation is expected to stay as snow and accumulate up to 12 inches.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 8 to 12 inches.
* WHERE...Haines Highway above 600 ft.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to midnight AKST Friday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult and is discouraged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest snowfall rates around Haines Customs is expected to be Friday morning with rates around 0.5 to 0.75 inches per hour.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT AKST FRIDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 12:48AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
Surface observations and nearby traffic cameras are indicating ongoing fog development along portions of the Treasure Coast and Okeechobee County this morning. Visibility of less than one-half mile at times is being observed. Fog is forecast to expand northward into portions of Osceola and Brevard County, producing visibility of less than one-half to one mile. If greater coverage and lower visibility materializes over the next few hours, a dense fog advisory will be necessary.
Motorists are encouraged to drive with caution by slowing down, using low-beam headlights, and increasing following distance when encountering fog this morning. Plan for extra travel time to destinations.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Osceola; Okeechobee; Coastal Indian River; Coastal St. Lucie; Coastal Martin; Inland Indian River; Inland St. Lucie; Inland Martin; Inland Southern Brevard; Mainland Southern Brevard; Southern Brevard Barrier Islands

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 8 at 12:11AM EST until March 8 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Vermont...
Winooski River At Essex Junction affecting Chittenden County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Winooski River at Essex Junction.
* WHEN...Until late this morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Farms in the Burlington Intervale begin to flood. Water will flood fields adjacent to North Williston Road in Essex and will approach North Williston Road. At 12.5 feet, North Williston Road in Essex will begin to flood, and motorists should seek an alternate route. Water will approach low lying farmland in the Burlington Intervale. At 13.0 feet, Water will cover North Williston Road in Essex and Pine Island Road in Colchester. Low lying farmland in the Burlington Intervale will flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 PM EST Thursday the stage was 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:30 PM EST Thursday was 13.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early this morning and continue falling to 7.1 feet early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 13.7 feet on 04/16/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 11:09PM EST by NWS Miami FL
entry.summary:
Areas of fog...some locally dense...are beginning to develop across Interior portions of South Florida. Visibilities are likely to be reduced to around 1 mile in general, with localized areas experiencing reduced visibilities to one-half of a mile at times. Fog will likely persist through the overnight and into the morning commute. If lower visibilities materialize, a dense fog advisory will be needed.
Motorists are advised to drive with caution tonight and Friday morning as visibilities may widely vary over short distances. Use low beam headlights and leave extra distance between your vehicle and others on the road when encountering significant reductions in visibility. Allow extra time to travel to destinations.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glades; Hendry; Inland Palm Beach County; Inland Collier County; Inland Broward County

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 8 at 2:03PM ChST until March 11 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, Large breaking waves of 10 to 12 feet, building to 13 feet over the weekend. For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding expected.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Monday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, from this afternoon through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is expected starting this afternoon, especially during high tide. Greatest risk will be along shores exposed to the northeast to east across the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher around the Marshall Islands. Please report any inundation to the local Weather Service Office (WSO).

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CHST MONDAY... ...COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 7 at 10:52PM EST until March 10 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of north and central Georgia including the following areas... Baldwin, Bibb, Butts, Crawford, Houston, Jasper, Jones, Monroe, Peach, Putnam, Twiggs, Wilkinson, Glascock, Greene, Hancock, Jefferson, Taliaferro, Warren, Washington, Wilkes, Barrow, Cherokee, Clayton, Cobb, Dawson, DeKalb, Douglas, Fannin, Fayette, Forsyth, Gilmer, Gwinnett, Hall, Henry, Lumpkin, Morgan, Newton, Fulton, Pickens, Rockdale, Union, Walton, Banks, Clarke, Jackson, Madison, Oconee, Oglethorpe, Towns, White, Bartow, Carroll, Catoosa, Chattooga, Dade, Floyd, Gordon, Haralson, Murray, Paulding, Polk, Walker, Whitfield, Chattahoochee, Coweta, Harris, Heard, Lamar, Macon, Marion, Meriwether, Muscogee, Pike, Schley, Spalding, Stewart, Talbot, Taylor, Troup, and Upson counties.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through late Saturday night.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:36PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
A developing moisture band over the North Pacific will stream northeast and into the panhandle starting mid next week. Rainfall total are looking moderate to heavy with 24 hour totals in the 1 to 2 inch range. The main item to watch is a nose of warmer air will move into the panhandle that will push freezing levels over 5000 feet across the southern panhandle and 1000 to 2000 over the north central panhandle.
The item to keep an eye on is additional snow melt from warming along with the rainfall of the heavier rainfall that stream flow will have higher water levels. We will continue to maintain a watch over this potential hazardous situation.

Water will approach homes on West Proctor Road near Route 4 in Rutland. Downstream in Proctor and Pittsford, numerous roads will flood, along with Route 73 west of Brandon. At 11.0 feet, Water will come near homes and businesses in Rutland along Otter Creek on Dorr Dr., Park St., Meadow St., Clement Rd., and along the confluence of Otter Creek and the Clarendon River at West Proctor Rd. and Rte 4. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 2:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A deep arctic trough will move south over the Western Interior and West Coast and bring well below normal temperatures beginning Friday night. Low temperatures by Saturday morning will be in the teens and 20s below zero and remain that way through Wednesday morning. Highs will range from near zero to 10 below. North winds of 10 to 30 mph with higher gusts in normally channeled areas including Shaktoolik, Johnson's Camp, and the Bering Strait are expected starting Friday night and lasting through the middle of next week as well. This, combined with lows dropping into the teens and 20s below zero, will bring wind chills into the 20s to 40s below zero by Friday night, with widepread wind chills of 35 to 45 below zero by Monday morning.
Residents and those traveling in the area are encouraged to be prepared for much colder than normal conditions.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:59PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary: An upper level disturbance will work together with a backdoor cold front to produce an area of snow showers midday Friday through late Friday night along the spine of the central mountain chain and the Continental Divide. Snow showers should quickly taper off early Saturday morning as overall lift and moisture decreases.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 7 at 1:42PM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
ESFSEW
A series of storm systems will spread moderate to heavy rainfall across Western Washington this weekend and into early next week. Storm total rainfall amounts of 3 to 6 inches are possible across the Olympic Peninsula. Snow levels near 2500-3000 ft may limit runoff amounts. This amount of prolonged rainfall has the potential to push the Skokomish River into flood stage.
Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued March 7 at 4:29PM EST until March 8 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one foot of inundation above ground level expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Kent, Inland Sussex and Delaware Beaches.
* WHEN...From 4 AM to 10 AM EST Friday.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 7 at 2:11PM CST by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
A period of steady rainfall is expected to move into the area on Friday, lingering into the evening. Widespread rainfall amounts up to one inch are possible across northeast Illinois and northwest Indiana, with amounts of 1-2 inches possible in isolated areas. Dormant vegetation and elevated soil moisture conditions will reduce infiltration and allow for much of this rainfall to runoff into area streams and rivers.
Ensemble river forecast guidance indicates the possibility of multiple rivers reaching bankfull due to this rainfall. Urban areas and poor drainage areas may also experience areas of standing water. While widespread flooding is not likely, a few river locations may near flood stage by this weekend.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
An update to this outlook will be issued by tomorrow morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cook, IL; DuPage, IL; Ford, IL; Grundy, IL; Iroquois, IL; Kankakee, IL; Kendall, IL; La Salle, IL; Livingston, IL; Will, IL; Benton, IN; Jasper, IN; Lake, IN; Newton, IN; Porter, IN

entry.summary:
Heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding is expected to arrive as early as midday Friday and may persist through Saturday afternoon. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches with locally higher amounts are likely. entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 6 at 3:01PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
ESFBIS
Given the recent cold weather, the Missouri River has again been forming ice below Garrison Dam. Thus far, ice has filled the recently cleared portion of the Missouri River from roughly Apple Creek Wildlife Management Area to about three-fourths of a mile upstream of where 12th street southeast turns into Oahe Bend. This would roughly be equal to a little less than five miles of new ice in the river.
The upstream edge of immobile ice as of Wednesday morning was roughly three and a half miles downstream of Fort Abraham Lincoln and Fox Island. While the future rate of ice formation is difficult to predict, forecast overnight lows in the single digits for both Thursday and Friday mornings will continue to encourage ice formation. It should be expected that the upstream edge of continuous ice on the river will migrate upstream. Based on how much ice has already been put in place, it is possible that the upstream edge of continuous ice will reach the Fox Island area before warmer weather enters the area on Friday. By late Saturday, warmer weather will once again reverse this process and start removing ice.
Importantly, pre-ice river levels were about 3.5 feet below that observed prior to last week's ice jam due to already planned lower releases out of Garrison Dam. This suggests that a return to water levels experienced in late February is not likely.

cap:parameter.value: MISSOURI RIVER IS ONCE AGAIN MAKING ICE
